thread.title: NEWS: State of Emergency Declared for Disney World as New Storm Develops
thread.title_full: NEWS: State of Emergency Declared for Disney World as New Storm Develops

author: Emily Burrus
title: NEWS: State of Emergency Declared for Disney World as New Storm Develops
text:
It’s
hurricane season which means you’re more likely to experience some severe weather on your trips to Disney World.
The season began on June 1st and ends on November 30th putting us in the middle.
We recently saw Hurricane Beryl and now another storm is on the way that may cause severe weather at Disney World.
As of Thursday, August 1st, Florida has declared a
state of emergency for 54 counties in the state. Osceola County and Orange County, the two that house Disney World, are included in the list.
According to
WFTV 9, a new major storm system is moving toward Florida and a potential hurricane could make landfall as soon as August 3rd, 2024. There’s a 30% chance of development over the next two days and a 70% chance over the next week.
NEW: Now a high chance (70%) from the National Hurricane Center of tropical development over this weekend in the Gulf of Mexico and near Florida. All of FL should monitor close, a strengthening tropical system could be in the cards as it passes over historically warm waters of…
[pic.twitter.com/TpVoC974oP]
— Noah Bergren (@NbergWX)
[August 1, 2024]
This comes after
the National Hurricane Center first reported a potential storm over the weekend. The storm is currently heading toward Florida and the eastern Gulf of Mexico where the warm tropical waters could help strengthen the storm into a hurricane. It would be called Hurricane Debby.
If you’re heading to Disney World, anywhere else in Florida, or the Gulf of Mexico, be sure to keep an eye on the weather reports. It’s unclear how exactly this will impact travel at the moment, but it will be easier to pivot if you are up to date on the latest. Read all about the storm below.
NEW Storm System Heading Toward Florida, According to the National Hurricane Center
This is a developing storm, so we’ll continue to keep you updated and let you know how it may impact your Disney World trip.
